Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?

Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Example:
juttai=nu wunagu=nu wu-ŋ
four.CLF:PERSON=GEN woman=NOM exist-IND
‘There are four women.’ (Masana)
wunagu=nu juttai wu-ŋ
woman=NOM four.CLF:PERSON exist-IND
‘There are four women.’ (Masana)

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Example:
aŋ tʃuu=wa ʔerabu=nu tʃuu DEM person=TOP Okinoerabu=GEN person COP:NEG-IND
‘That person is not from Okinoerabu.’

taro:-ta
Taro-ASS

put.away-NMLZ

put.away-NMLZ

Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Comment: the nominative marker -ga is used for kinship terms and occupation nouns (‘the hand of the teacher’, ‘his car’), in other instances -nu is used. It is not clear whether this distribution can be attributed to alienability
Example:
ʃinʃi:=ga ti:
teacher=NOM/GEN hand
‘the hand of the teacher’

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Example:
ʃinʃi:=ga ti:
teacher=NOM/GEN hand
‘the hand of the teacher’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Example:

friend=NOM port=LIM bring-MED BEN-PST-IND ‘My friend brought me to the port.’ (Kunigami)

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?

Example:

port=LIM car=INS bring-NPST-IND ‘I will bring him to the port by car.’ (Kunigami)

Are there postpositions?

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?

Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Detailed comment: “A declarative sentence with a nominal predicate only takes the copula *jamu/*jaŋ in the case that tense inflection, or non-finite inflection, or a conjunction is used”
Example:
nunsa taasa-nu çii =dʒa
very be.tall-ADN tree ASRT ‘That’s a very tall tree.’ (Masana)
ʔorandadʒiŋ jan-tu=du ʔoranda=nu muni gai-rar-i-ru
Dutchman COP-because=FOC Netherlands=GEN language say-POT-NPST-EMPH ‘It’s because he’s a Dutchman that he can speak Dutch.’ (Masana)

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Comment: the “auxiliary verb” mentioned in the grammar seems to be phonologically bound (followed by an indicative suffix and a quotative particle)
Detailed comment: “The desiderative mood is indicated by the use of auxiliary property concept verb -buʃaamu (Masana)”
Example:
Masana=tu <koorjuu> ʃii-buʃaa-mu=di
Masana=COM exchange do-DES-IND=QUOT ‘They said they want a [cultural] exchange with Masana.’ (Masana)

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Detailed comment: resultative: medial form of the verb + Ɂa:mu
Example:
nama ʔama=wa tanʃi=gatʃi kibara noo-tʃu-mu
now mother=TOP cupboard=DIR clothes put.away-PROG-IND
‘Mother is putting away the clothes in the cupboard now.’ (Masana)

Feature: Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Is verb compounding a regular process?
Comment: the desiderative mood is marked by an “auxiliary verb”, which appears to be phonologically bound
Detailed comment: "The desiderative mood is indicated by the use of auxiliary property concept verb -buʃaamu (Masana)/-buʃaŋ (Kunigami).”
Example:
Masana=tu <koorjuu> ʃii-buʃaa-mu=di
Masana=COM exchange do-DES-IND=QUOT ‘They said they want a [cultural] exchange with Masana.’ (Masana)

wan-tʃi deŋwa ʃi-ri=jo:
1SG-DIR phone do-IMP=ASRT
‘Give me a call.’ (Kunigami)
